J'AI rencontre par hasard a Prague des pei-sounes reutrees receniment de Russie,ou elles ont assiste aux fetes du 100 anuiversaire de 1'institution du regime desSoviets. De nationalites differentes, la plupart de ces personnes etaient desjournalistes, des professeurs, des litterateurs. An cours des conversations que j'aieues avec elles, j'ai ete frappe par le fait que malgre la difference de leurs professionset de leurs nationalites, leurs impressions geuerales concordaient. Je ne puis redirodans cette note tous leurs propos, car elle serait trop longue : je me bornerai a relalerce qu'elles m'ont dit de plus important. Le regime sovietique donne 1'impression d'uue graude stabilite. La vieeconomique a reprise et progresse continuellement; la production a atteiut presquepartout le niveau de celle d'avant-guerre. Vis-a-vis de 1'opposition, le Gouvernementaetuel parait etre tres fort et Ton peut s'attendre sous peu a des mesures de rigueurcontre les chefs de cette opposition. II semble, cependant, qu'on fera une concession ala masse de 1'opposition, par la demission de Staline, demission qui sera acceptee. La grande difficulte contre laquelle se debat le regime actuel, qui peut menacersa base politique elle-meme, est le manque de fonds. cost pourquoi les dirigeantsconscients de ce danger, font des efforts inouis pour se procurer des emprunts qui leurpermettraient de poursuivre le developpement de leur activite. Toute 1'activiteeconomique semble menacee si des emprunts importants ne se concluent pas rapide-ment. Faute d'argent, le chomage, qui sevit beaucoup a Moscou et dans les grandscentres, augmenterait encore et pourrait produire des troubles Ires graves. Lech6mage, selon mes interlocuteurs, s'explique de la facon suivante: Dans les villagesun grand nombre de gens ne peuvent trouver du travail, malgre la regime actuel oupeut-etre a cause de lui. Comme les terres sont distributes a des individus et qu'iln'existe plus de grandes etendues appartenant a un seul, le paysan travaille seul avecsa famille ou avec peu d'ouvriers agi-icoles. D'autres faits forcent le paysan a chercherdu travail a la ville: 1'alcoolisme et la cherte de tous les articles fabriques.L'augmentation de la consommation de 1'alcool est considerable ; elle depasse celle de1'epoquo tsariste, et 1'Etat ne fait rieu pour la diminuer ; au contraire, il en est satisfait,car 1'alcool est une des ressources les plus importantes du budget actuel. Ces deuxfacteurs alcoolisme et cherte de vie forcent souvent le paysan a vendre sa terre et le poussent vers la ville. Cest pourquoi arrivent a. Moscou chaque jour des centaineset meme des milliers de gens qui cherchent du travail et un abri et ne trouvent ni l'un ni1'autre. Ceci force le Gouvernement a augmenter 1'activite industrielle. S'il ne trouvepas les fonds dont il a besoin pour developper 1'industrie et parer au chomage, ilrisque de voir se creer un proletariat extrSmement dangereux dans les grands centreset surtout a Moscou, ce qui pourrait a nouveau mettre le Gouvernement actuel en peril,malgre la force dont il dispose. Les dirigeants esperent obtenir des empruntsimportants et ils comptent surtout sur TAllemagne, qui leur obtiendrait les fondsnecessaires de 1'Amerique. Si la vie a Moscoii est tres difficile, par contre la vie a Petrograd parait beaucoupplus agreable. La crise des logements n'existe, pour ainsi dire, pas a Petrograd, lasurveillance par les autorites y est moms grande qu'a Moscou et les gens paraissentplus contents et parlent avec plus de franchise. Si a Moscou la vie politiqne, la vieeconomique et, jusqu'a un certain point la vie artistique (surtout au point de vue 42.^6 [16929] theatre) y sout concentrees, c'est a Petrograrl que sVst plfitot refugiee la vie scientifique. Chose curieuse, la plupart des professeura qui ont vraiment un nom dans le raonde scientifique sont ouverlcment anti-bolchevistes, bien qu'ils collaborent loyalement avec le Gouvernemcnt actuel. 0'est mi fait connu et dont les hommes en question ne font pas secret. On m'a signale egalement que la vie scientifique est orientee, d'une facou tres marquante, vers les questions asiatiques. La raison de cette orientation est double : 1. Le Gouvernement assure son appui a tout homnie de science qui vent s'occuper du probleme asiatique; 2. LMnteret general se porle actuellement vers 1'Asie. Une serie de travaux tres iniportants sont entrepris au sujet de 1'Asie. Des missions scientifiques parcourent la Siberie, la Mongolie, le Turkestan russe et autres regions asiatiques et font des decouvertes interessautes au point de vue geologique, ethnographique, geographique, &c. On cherche a mettre en valeur les graudes richesses de cette partie du continent et on eherche egalement a bien connaitre les differents peuples qui habitent la Siberie, a les organiser nationalement, a leur donuer une langue litteraire, a les developper en taut qu'individus. Ces efforts, contraires jusqu'a un certain j)oint a la politique tsariste, sont faits dans 1'idee que la force de la Uussie sovietique consiste justement dans le developpe- ment du nationalismo des peuples asiatiques. Cest aussi un excellent moyen de propagande en deliors des frontieres de la Russie et qui donne deja ses fruits, d'ailleurs inattendus. A 1'occasion des fetes auxquelles ils out assiste, nies iuterlocuteurs out ete frappes par les representations solennelles de la plupart des pays asiatiques. Ils ont eu 1'occasion de parler avec quelques-uns des representants de ces Gouvernements asiatiques et ont pu constater com bien s'accroit en Asie le prestige de la Russie. Tons ces peuples ne considerent plus la Russie telle qu'elle etait, mais comme une union des differents peuples ; ils ne craignent plus son esprit de conquete et acceptent volontiers son influence. La Russie sovietique ne leur semble pas un danger pour leur independance, mais plutot ime protection contre les autres pays, dont ils soupgonuent les gouts imperialistes. Pendant la grande revue militaire, mes interlocuteurs ont ete frappes du grand enthousiasme que 1'apparition de 1'armee rouge a provoque chez le peuple russe. Get enthousiasme est du, en grande partie, a une propagande militariste extremement active faite en Russie. On m'a montre un immense paquet de brochures populaires, de feuilles detachees, &c, qui sont distributes dans les rues de Aloscou et d'autres villes et qui glorifient 1'armee rouge. Elles ont pour but d'amener les hommes au service volontaire, elles demontrent rimportance de l'aviation et que la guerre n'est pas contraire aux doctrines marxistes, &c. Si riufanterie parait dans un etat assez mediocre, 1'equipement des troupestechniques, surtout de 1'artillerie, est magnifique. Mes interlocuteurs pensent queTon a sans doute choisi pour ces revues les troupes d'elite, afin de faire impression surles delegues etrangers, mais, meme en tenant compte de cette raison, 1'equipement do1'armee rouge merite une mention speciale. Si Ton remarque encore 1'excellente cavalei-ie dont la Russie dispose et dont elle a toiijours dispose, du reste, on en arrive a la conclusion que 1'armee rouge est deja interessante et peut devenir vraimeut respectable. Presque tous mes interlocuteurs sont des gens qui connaissaient bien la Russie avant la guerre. Tous conuaissent bien le russe et ont des amis personnels dans le pays. Ils m'ont donue quelques details amusants sur 1'habilete avec laquelle les dirigeants de la Russie fojit leur propagande. Ils m'ont parle du tombeau de Lenine, devaixt lequel passe un defile incessant de paysans, ce qui frappe beaucoup les etrangers ; il faut en effet atteudre une heure on deux avant de parvenir au mausolee. II semble done que los paysans sont devenus de fervents admirateurs du i-egime bolchevique, mais on'decouvre vite la raison veritable de cette ferveur. Les moujiks russes ont toujours considere un cadavre conserve comme quelque chose de surnaturel; ils ont. toujours fait des pelerinages aux reliques. Les paysans considerent Lenine comme un nouveau saint, et lorsqu'ils defilent devant son tombeau, ils s'y agenouillent et adressent des prieres au cadavre embaume. Ce n'est pas le fondateur de la Russie sovietique, ce n'est pas 1'apotre du marxiste qu'ils venerent, c'est tout simplemeut lo plus recent des saints de Russie auquel ils rehlanient protection aupres du Bon Dieu. Un phenomene qui frappe les personues connaissant la Russie d'avant-guerre estTinimense prestige dont jouit 1'Allemagne actuellement daus leB milieux russes. Ceprestige se manifeste de bien des mauieres. On m'a signale que dans le cortege des mannequins representant les hominesd'that de tons les pays on n'a pas trouve un seul mannequin ligurant un hommepolitique allemand, sauf celui du chef clu parti socialiste allemand. On m'a signal^egalement que pendant le diner officiel la rentree de 1'Ambassadeur allemand a donne"lieu a xme sorte de manifestation: a ce moment tous les Russes se trouvant dans lasalle se sont leves et la plupart se sont precipites vers 1'Ambassadeur pour le saluer,alors que les autres representants de pays out ete salues tres normalement. Plusieurs de mes interlocuteurs se sont entretenus des questions de politiquointernationale avec differentes personnalites bolchevistes, et avec. M. Tchitcherinelui-meine. Us ont garde l'impre6sion que la Russia, actuellement, ne pense pas aune guerre (1'agression, mais qu'elle est neaumoins serieusement preoccupee d'unepossibilite de guerre prochaine. Deux points, selon les dirigeants de Moscou,pourraient entrainer la Russie a laire la guerre : 1. On soupconne les Polonais d'avoir des intentions hostiles a 1'egard de la Lithuanie et de vouloir renouveler pour Kovno le coup de Vilna. D'apres M. Tchitcherine, un tel coup serait un signal immtdiat pour 1'U.R.S.S., qui ne pourrait tolerer qu'on attaque la Lithuanie et qui interviendrait alors par les armes. 2. On soupsonne le Gouvernement britannique de fomenter un coup d'l5tat en Afghanistan, atin de supprimer le Gouvernenient actuel de ce pays. Si cette eventualite se produisait, 1U.R.S.S. recourrait ii une intervention armee en Afghanistan . . . . et ce pourrait etre le dtbut d'une grande guerre. [Information derived from a good French source is to the effect that the French Government put a very low value on the Soviet army as a fighting machine and does not at all support the view of the Czech as to its equipment.] The Following is a very rough translation of O.P. 211(27); the translator does not guarantee it to "be void of errors. - C.H.W.-I. I met, by chance, in Prague some people recently re- turned from Russia, where they had assisted at the celebrations- bration of the tenth anniversary of the establishment of the Soviet regime. Of different nationalities, most of these people were Journalists, professors or literary men. In the course of conversations which I had with them, I was struck by the fact that, in spite of the variety of their professions and of their nationalities, their gen- eral impressions were the same. I am not able to set out in this note all their views, for th-t would take up too much space: I will confine myself to recording the most important ones. The Soviet regime gives the impression of great stab- ility. The economic life has revived and steadily improves: production has almost reached the pre-war level. In re- lation to the opposition, the existing Government appears to be very strong and it may be expected to take before long some vigorous measures against the leaders of that opposition. It seems, however, that a concession will be made to the mass of the opposition, by the dismissal of Stalin, a dismissal which will be accepted. The great difficulty which besets the existing regime, whioh may threaten its very political foundation, is the lack of funds. That is why the authorities, conscious of this danger, are making unadvertised efforts to obtain loans which will enable them to further the development of their activities. The entire economic activity seems to be threatened if important loans are not very soon arranged. Failing money, unemployment, which is rife in moscow and in the other great centres, will increase still further and may produce very serious troubles. Unemployment,according to my informants, arises from the following causes:in the villages a great number of people cannot find work, inspite of the existing rAgime, or perhaps because of it. Asthe land is divided between these individuals, ana as there nolonger exist large estates belonging to a single landlord, the peasant works only with his family or with a few agricultural workers. Other circumstances compel the peasant to seek workin the towns; drink and the high prices of all manufacturedgoods. The increase in the consumption of alcohol is oonsider-able: it surpasses that of the tsarist period, and the Statedoes nothing to lessen it: on the contrary, it encourages it,because alcohol is one of the most important sources of revenueThese two factors - drink and high prices - often compel the peasant to sell his land and migrate to the towns. That is why every day sees arrive in Moscow hundreds and even thousands of people seeking work and a roof over their heads, but findingneither the one nor the other. This compels the Government toincrease its industrial activity. If it is unable to finck themoney it needs for the development of industry and for thereduction of unemployment, it runs the risk of seeing thecreation of an extremely dangerous proletariat in the largecentres and especially in Moscow, which might again place theGovernment in peril, in spite of the force which it controls.The authorities hope to obtain important loans and are countingspecially on Germany, who will obtain the necessary funds forthem from America. If life in Moscow is very difficult, the contrary appliesin Petrograd where life appears most agreeable. The Housingproblem does not, so to speak, exist in Petrograd, supervisionby the authorities there is less in evidence than in moscow and the people seem more content and speak morw freely. Thoughat Moscow politics, economics and, up to a certain point, art(speoially from the point of view of the theatre) are concen-trated, it is to Petrograd that science has betaken itself. A remarkable fact is, most of the professors who are reallyrenowned in the woyld of science are openly anti-bolshevist,while thay collaborate loyally with the existing Government.It is a known fact, and one of which the men in question make no secret. It was also pointed out to me how science is directed, ina most remarkable manner, to Asiatic questions. There is a double reason for this orientation: - 1. The Government promises its support to every scientist who is willing to interest himself in the Asiatic problem; 2. The general interest tends actually towards Asia. A series of very important operations are being under- taken on the subject of Asia. Scientific missions are overrunning Siberia, Mongolia, Russian Turkestan and other Asiatic regions and have made interesting discoveries - geological, ethnographical, geograph- ical &c. They are seeking to estimate the great wealth of this part of the Continent and they are seek ing at the same time to get acquainted with the diff- different peoples who inherit Siberia, to organise them nationally, to give them a written language and to educate them individually. These efforts, opposed, up to a point, to tsarist politics,are made with the idea that the power of Soviet Russia rightlyconsists in the development of the nationalism of the Asiaticraces. It is thus an excellent means of propaganda outside the frontiers of Russia, which is alraady bearing fruit, albeitunexpected. On the occasion of the celebrations in which they assisted,my informants were impressed by the formal representation of most of the Asiatic countries. They Rah apportunities to con-verse with several of the representatives of these AsiaticGovernments and were able to gauge how deeply Russian prestigehad taken root in Asia. All these peoples no longer consider Russia what she was formerly, but as a union of differentpeoples: they no longer fear her lust for conquest and willing-ly accept her influence. Soviet Russia does not seem to thema danger to their independence, but rather a protection againstother countries, whom they suspect of having imperialistic Itendencies. I During the great military review, my informants were im-pressed by the great enthusiasm which the appearance of theRed Army evoked amongst the Russians themselves. This entims-iasm is due, very largely, to an extremely active militaristicpropaganda in Russia. I was shown an immense bundle of popularpamphlets, leaflets &c, which are distributed in the streetsof Moscow and other towns and which belaud the Red Army. Theyare intended to attract volunteers, to show the importance of aviation and to show that war is not contrary to Marxian doc-trines, &c. Though the infantry appears to be in a somewhat indiffer-ent condition, the equipment of the technical troops - special-ly the artillery - is magnificent. My informants think thatthe 1 crack' troops were doubtless selected for these reviews,to make an impression on foreign representatives, but, whilsttaking this point into consideration, the equipment of the red army does indeed deserve special mention. Whilst, again, theyremarked on the excellent cavalry which Russia possesses andhas always possessed, at the same time they arrived at theconclusion that the Red Army is already interesting and may become really respectable. lleaily all my informants are people who knew Russia well before the war. They all know.the Russian well and have per-sonal friends in the country. They gave me some amusing de-tails of the method by whioh the leaders of Russia organisetheir propaganda. They referred to Lenin's tomb, before whioha constant stream of peasants files, a fact which much im-presses foreigners; one has indeed to wait an hour or two before reaching the mausoleum. It seems then that the peasants have become fervent admirers of the bolshevist regime but onesoon discovers the real reason for this fervour. The Russian"moujiks" have always been regarded as a class conservativeabove the ordinary; they have always made pilgrimages toshrines. The peasants reggriri Lenin as a new saint, and whenthey pass before his tomb, they fall on their knees and prayto the embalmed corpse. It is not the founder of - fry SovietRussia nor the apostle of Marx whom they revere, it is simplythe newest saint in the Russian Calendar to whom they prayfor protection next only to le Bon Dieu. A remarkable thing which strikes people who knew Russiabefore the war is the great prestige enjoyed by present-dayGermany amongst the Russians. This prestige is manifested invarious ways. It was mentioned to me that in the procession of figuresrepresenting the statesmen of allji the nations, there was nota single figure representing a German politician, saving only that of the leader of the German socialist Party. It was also mentioned that during the official banquet the entry of theGerman Ambassador was made the excuse for a xlnd of demonstrateion: all the Russians in the room at the time rose to theirfeet and most of them hastened towards the Ambassador to greethim whilst the representatives of the other nations weregreeted quite formally. Several of my informants discussed questions of inter-national politics with different bolshevist personalities,and even with M. Tchitcherine himself. They formed the im-pression that Russia, in reality, does not contemplate a "war of aggression, but that she is, none the less, seriously pre-occupied with the possibility of a war in the near future.Two things, according to the leaders at Moscow, would be ableto drive Russia to make war: - 1. They suspect the Poles of having hostile intentions with regard to Lithuania and of contemplating a coup at Kovno similar to that at Vilna. According to M. Tchitoherine, such a coup would be the immediate signal for the U.S.S.B.. t which could not tolerate an attack onLithuania and whizhh would intervene with all its forces. 2. They suspect the British Government of engineeringa coup d'dtat in Afghanistan, with a view to suppressing theexisting Government of that country. If that eventualityshould materialise-, the U.S. S.R. would have recourse to armedintervention in Afghanistan .... and that would he thebeginning of a great war.
